title: How to Make Jalapeño Jelly

steps.headline: Choose ripened jalapeños for the best results.
steps.description: When you are shopping for jalapeños look for the ones which are about 4 to 6 inches long, firm to the touch, and bright green. These are the common features of ripened jalepeños and will make the best flavored jelly.

steps.headline: Remove the stems and seeds from all of the jalapeños.
steps.description: Cut them into halves, exposing the seeds, and use a spoon to scrape all of the seeds out. You can either cut off the top part of the jalapeños to remove the stems or just pull them off. You will not want to find any seeds in your finished jelly and the stems will simply not taste very good.

steps.headline: Purée the jalapeños with a cup of vinegar.
steps.description: Place your jalapeños into a food processor along with 1 cup of apple cider vinegar. proceed blend the mixture until it is smooth.

steps.headline: Pour the pepper purée into a saucepan and boil.
steps.description: You will want to add another 1 cup of apple cider vinegar to the purée and heat the mixture to a roiling boil.

steps.headline: Add sugar to the boiling purée.
steps.description: Once your purée has reached a roiling boil you will need to add 6 cups of sugar to the mixture and continuously stir the boiling mixture for the next ten minutes.

steps.headline: Add pectin after ten minutes.
steps.description: You will need to add 6 oz of liquid pectin to the boiling mixture. Keep stirring for one more minute after the pectin has been added and then immediately remove from the heat. Pectin is the ingredient which makes the jelly actually gel!

steps.headline: Pour the hot jelly into jars.
steps.description: Use a funnel when pouring the hot jelly, it will be much less messy! Leave about a quarter of an inch of free space at the top of the jars. When you process the jars the jelly will expand a little bit and you wouldn't want to break a jar.

steps.headline: Process the jars in a water canner filled with boiling water.
steps.description: You now need to place the closed jars into the water canner and boil them for 10 minutes at a high heat, this will ensure that the jars are tightly sealed and preserved. When removing the jars from the water use tongs in order to not burn yourself. You can expect that the jelly should last about 6 to 9 months from the day it is made!
